Summary I am a mediator and alternative dispute professional. My interest in this field stems from my experiences living in cooperative housing, being a member of social justice groups that function on consensus, and from my strong commitment to the transformative power of effective communication. To be welcomed in to have a discussion with people in conflict is a privilege.  
 
I graduated from Northeastern University School of Law in May of 2014 and from Stanford University in June 2009. While a law student, I was active in the school’s National Lawyers Guild chapter. I also participated in Northeastern’s Poverty Law Clinic, where I represented clients in unemployment, TAFDC, and SNAP cases. On law school internships, I worked as a project manager at Boston Law Collaborative, did municipal-level policy work and handled claims of housing and employment discrimination at San Francisco’s municipal civil rights commission, helped with post-conviction capital defense work at the Georgia Resource Center, and participated in grassroots drafting of and advocacy for local legislation about various policies in the War on Terror at the Bill of Rights Defense Committee. 
 
Prior to law school, I was a union organizer and grievance representative in higher education, a scientist researching the cause of bee colony collapse disorder, and a blogger on the War on Terror.
